# Sodom and Gomorrah

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

This article is about the biblical cities. For other uses, see [Sodom and
Gomorrah (disambiguation)](/wiki/Sodom_and_Gomorrah_\(disambiguation\) "Sodom
and Gomorrah \(disambiguation\)").

Sodom and Gomorrah being destroyed in the background of [Lucas van

**Sodom** and **Gomorrah** ([/ˈsɒdəm/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English
"Help:IPA/English"); [/ɡəˈmɔːrə/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English
"Help:IPA/English")[1]) were cities mentioned in the [Book of
Genesis](/wiki/Book_of_Genesis "Book of Genesis")[2] and throughout the
[Hebrew Bible](/wiki/Hebrew_Bible "Hebrew Bible"),[3] the [New
Testament](/wiki/New_Testament "New Testament") and in the [deuterocanonical
books](/wiki/Deuterocanonical_books "Deuterocanonical books"), as well as in
the [Quran](/wiki/Quran "Quran") and the [hadith](/wiki/Hadith "Hadith").[4]

According to the [Torah](/wiki/Torah "Torah"), the kingdoms of Sodom and
Gomorrah were allied with the cities of [Admah](/wiki/Admah "Admah"),
[Zeboim](/wiki/Zeboim_\(biblical\) "Zeboim \(biblical\)") and
[Bela](/wiki/Zoara "Zoara"). These five cities, also known as the "cities of
the plain" (from Genesis in the [Authorized Version](/wiki/Authorized_Version
"Authorized Version")), were situated on the [Jordan River](/wiki/River_Jordan
"River Jordan") plain in the southern region of the land of
[Canaan](/wiki/Canaan "Canaan"). The plain, which corresponds to the area just
north of the modern-day [Dead Sea](/wiki/Dead_Sea "Dead Sea"),[5] was compared
to the garden of
Eden[[Gen.13:10]](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Genesis+13%3A10&version=NIV)
as being well-watered and green, suitable for grazing livestock.

[Divine judgment](/wiki/Divine_judgment "Divine judgment") by [God](/wiki/God
"God") was passed upon Sodom and Gomorrah and two neighboring cities, which
were completely consumed by [fire and brimstone](/wiki/Fire_and_brimstone
"Fire and brimstone"). Neighboring [Zoar](/wiki/Zoara "Zoara") (Bela) was the
only city to be spared. In [Abrahamic religions](/wiki/Abrahamic_religions
"Abrahamic religions"), Sodom and Gomorrah have become synonymous with
impenitent sin, and their fall with a proverbial manifestation of [divine
retribution](/wiki/Divine_retribution "Divine retribution").[6][7][[Jude
1:7]](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Jude+1%3A7&version=NRSV)
Sodom and Gomorrah have been used historically and today as
[metaphors](/wiki/Metaphor "Metaphor") for [vice](/wiki/Vice "Vice") and
[homosexuality](/wiki/Homosexuality "Homosexuality"), although a close reading
of the text and other Ancient Near Eastern sources suggest that this
association may be incorrect.[8]

The story has therefore given rise to words in several languages. These
include the English word _[sodomy](/wiki/Sodomy "Sodomy")_ , which is used in
[sodomy laws](/wiki/Sodomy_law "Sodomy law") to describe sexual "crimes
against nature", namely [anal](/wiki/Anal_sex "Anal sex") or [oral
sex](/wiki/Oral_sex "Oral sex") (particularly [homosexual](/wiki/Homosexual
"Homosexual")), or [bestiality](/wiki/Bestiality "Bestiality").[9][10][11]
Some Islamic societies incorporate punishments associated with Sodom and
Gomorrah into [sharia](/wiki/Sharia "Sharia").[12]

##
Etymology[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sodom_and_Gomorrah&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Etymology")]

The etymology of both names is uncertain.[13] The exact original meanings of
the names are also uncertain. Some believe, the name _Sodom_
([Hebrew](/wiki/Hebrew_language "Hebrew language"): סְדֹם‎ _Səḏōm_) could be a
word from an early Semitic language ultimately related to the Arabic _sadama_
, meaning "fasten", "fortify", "strengthen", but that is unlikely as the
Gesenius' Hebrew-Chaldee Lexicon defines the hebrew word Sodom (Cēdom) as
burning.[14] Gomorrah ([Hebrew](/wiki/Hebrew_language "Hebrew language"):
עֲמֹרָה‎ _‘Ămōrāh_) could be based on the root _gh m r_ , which means "be
deep", "copious (water),"[15] but this is also in dispute as it is classically
known as עֲמֹרָה ʻĂmôrâh, am-o-raw'; from H6014; a (ruined) heap; Amorah, a
place in Palestine:—Gomorrah.[16]

##
Historicity[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sodom_and_Gomorrah&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Historicity")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Pillar_of_salt_at_Usdum.jpg/220px-
Pillar_of_salt_at_Usdum.jpg)](/wiki/File:Pillar_of_salt_at_Usdum.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Pillar_of_salt_at_Usdum.jpg "Enlarge")

Painting from [William Francis Lynch](/wiki/William_Francis_Lynch "William
Francis Lynch") book _The Narrative of the United States Expedition of the
River Jordan and the Dead Sea_. Published in 1849

There are other stories and historical names which bear a resemblance to the
Biblical stories of Sodom and Gomorrah. Some possible natural explanations for
the events described have been proposed, but no widely accepted or strongly
verified sites for the cities have been found. Of the five "cities of the
plain", only Bela, modern-day [Zoara](/wiki/Zoara "Zoara"), is securely
identified, and it remained a settlement long after the biblical period.

The ancient Greek historiographer [Strabo](/wiki/Strabo "Strabo") states that
locals living near Moasada (as opposed to [Masada](/wiki/Masada "Masada")) say
that "there were once thirteen inhabited cities in that region of which Sodom
was the metropolis". Strabo identifies [a limestone and salt
hill](/wiki/Mount_Sodom "Mount Sodom") at the south western tip of the Dead
Sea, and [Kharbet Usdum](/wiki/Mount_Sodom "Mount Sodom") (Hebrew: הר סדום,
_Har Sedom_ or Arabic: جبل السدوم, _Jabal(u) 'ssudūm_) ruins nearby as the
site of biblical Sodom.[17] [Archibald Sayce](/wiki/Archibald_Sayce "Archibald
Sayce") translated an [Akkadian](/wiki/Akkadian_language "Akkadian language")
poem describing cities that were destroyed in a rain of fire, written from the
view of a person who escaped the destruction; the names of the cities are not
given.[18] However, Sayce later mentions that the story more closely resembles
the doom of [Sennacherib](/wiki/Sennacherib "Sennacherib")'s host.[19]

In 1976 [Giovanni Pettinato](/wiki/Giovanni_Pettinato "Giovanni Pettinato")
claimed that a [cuneiform](/wiki/Cuneiform "Cuneiform") tablet that had been
found in the newly discovered library at [Ebla](/wiki/Ebla "Ebla") contained
the names of all five of the cities of the plain (Sodom, Gomorrah,
[Admah](/wiki/Admah "Admah"), [Zeboim](/wiki/Zeboim_\(Hebrew_Bible\) "Zeboim
\(Hebrew Bible\)"), and [Bela](/wiki/Zoara "Zoara")), listed in the same order
as in Genesis. The names _si-da-mu_ [TM.76.G.524] and _ì-ma-ar_ [TM.75.G.1570
and TM.75.G.2233] were identified as representing Sodom and Gomorrah, which
gained some acceptance at the time.[20] However, Alfonso Archi states that,
judging from the surrounding city names in the cuneiform list, _si-da-mu_ lies
in northern Syria and not near the Dead Sea, and _ì-ma-ar_ is a variant of _ì-
mar_ , known to represent [Emar](/wiki/Emar "Emar"), an ancient city located
near Ebla.[21] Today, the scholarly consensus is that "Ebla has no bearing on
... Sodom and Gomorra."[22]

Certain skeptics of the biblical account have theorized that, provided that
the cities existed at all, that they might have been destroyed by [natural
disaster](/wiki/Natural_disaster "Natural disaster"). One such idea is that
the Dead Sea was devastated by an [earthquake](/wiki/Earthquake "Earthquake")
between 2100 and 1900 BCE. This might have unleashed showers of steaming
tar.[23] It is possible that the towns were destroyed by an earthquake,
especially if they lay along a major fault such as the [Jordan Rift
Valley](/wiki/Jordan_Rift_Valley "Jordan Rift Valley"). There is a lack of
contemporary accounts of seismic activity within the necessary timeframe,
however, to corroborate this theory.[24] Another idea is that the destruction
was caused by the plume of a [meteor](/wiki/Meteor "Meteor") that impacted in
the Alps, as possibly shown in a [planisphere](/wiki/Planisphere
"Planisphere") inscribed on a cuneiform tablet. [25]

In 1973, Walter E. Rast and R. Thomas Schaub discovered or visited a number of
possible sites of the cities, including [Bab edh-Dhra](/wiki/Bab_edh-Dhra "Bab
edh-Dhra"), which was originally excavated in 1965 by archaeologist Paul Lapp,
and later finished by Rast and Schaub following his death. Other possibilities
include [Numeira](/wiki/Numeira "Numeira"), al-Safi, Feifa, and
[Khanazir](/wiki/Khanazir "Khanazir"), which were also visited by Schaub and
Rast. Each of the sites were near the [Dead Sea](/wiki/Dead_Sea "Dead Sea")
and showed evidence of burning and traces of [sulfur](/wiki/Sulfur
"Sulfur").[26][27] According to Schaub, however, who dug at Bab edh-Dhra,
Numeira was destroyed in 2600 BCE at a different time period than Bab edh-Dhra
(2350–2067 BCE).[28] Archaeological remains excavated from Bab edh-Dhra are
currently displayed in [Karak Archaeological
Museum](/wiki/Karak_Archaeological_Museum "Karak Archaeological Museum")
(Karak Castle), [Amman Citadel](/wiki/Amman_Citadel "Amman Citadel") Museum,
and the [British Museum](/wiki/British_Museum "British Museum").

Another candidate for Sodom is the [Tall el Hammam](/wiki/Tall_el-
Hammam_Excavation_Project "Tall el-Hammam Excavation Project") dig site which
began in 2006 under the direction of [Steven
Collins](/wiki/Steven_Collins_\(archaeologist\) "Steven Collins
\(archaeologist\)"). Tall el Hammam is located in the southern Jordan river
valley approximately 14 kilometres (9 mi) northeast of the Dead Sea, and
according to Collins fits the biblical descriptions of the lands of
Sodom.[29][30] The ongoing dig is a result of joint cooperation between
[Trinity Southwest University](/wiki/Trinity_Southwest_University "Trinity
Southwest University") and the Department of Antiquities of the [Hashemite
Kingdom of Jordan](/wiki/Hashemite_Kingdom_of_Jordan "Hashemite Kingdom of
Jordan").[31][_[better source needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS
"Wikipedia:NOTRS")_]

Professor [Eugene H. Merrill](/wiki/Eugene_H._Merrill_\(academic\) "Eugene H.
Merrill \(academic\)") believes that the identification of Tall el-Hammam with
Sodom would require an unacceptable restructuring of the biblical
chronology.[32][33][34]

The Jewish historian [Josephus](/wiki/Josephus "Josephus") identifies the
[Dead Sea](/wiki/Dead_Sea "Dead Sea") in geographic proximity to the ancient
biblical city of Sodom. He refers to the lake by its Greek name,
Asphaltites.[35]

## In the Book of
Genesis[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sodom_and_Gomorrah&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: In the Book of Genesis")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg) |  This section **does not[cite](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources") any [sources](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")**. Please help [improve this section](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Sodom_and_Gomorrah&action=edit) by [adding citations to reliable sources](/wiki/Help:Introduction_to_referencing_with_Wiki_Markup/1 "Help:Introduction to referencing with Wiki Markup/1"). Unsourced material may be challenged and [removed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability#Burden_of_evidence "Wikipedia:Verifiability"). _(August 2017)_ _([Learn how and when to remove this template message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))_

The [Book of Genesis](/wiki/Book_of_Genesis "Book of Genesis") is the primary
source that mentions the cities of Sodom and Gomorrah.

### Battle of
Siddim[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sodom_and_Gomorrah&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Battle of Siddim")]

See also: [Battle of Siddim](/wiki/Battle_of_Siddim "Battle of Siddim")

The Battle of Siddim is described in [Genesis 14:1-17](http://www.mechon-
mamre.org/p/pt/pt0114.htm#1). Sodom and Gomorrah's political situation is
described when [Lot](/wiki/Lot_\(biblical_person\) "Lot \(biblical person\)")
had encamped in Sodom's territory. At this time, "the men of Sodom [were]
wicked and sinners before the LORD exceedingly". Sodom was ruled by King
[Bera](/wiki/Bera_\(Bible\) "Bera \(Bible\)") while Gomorrah was ruled by King
[Birsha](/wiki/Birsha "Birsha"). Their kingship, however, was not sovereign,
because all of the river Jordan plain was under [Elamite](/wiki/Elam "Elam")
rule for 12 years. The kingdom of Elam was ruled by King
[Chedorlaomer](/wiki/Chedorlaomer "Chedorlaomer"). In the 13th year of
subjugation to Elam, the five kings of the river Jordan plain allied to rebel
against Elamite rule. These kings included those of Sodom and Gomorrah as well
as their neighbors: King [Shinab](/wiki/Shinab "Shinab") of
[Admah](/wiki/Admah "Admah"), King [Shemeber](/wiki/Shemeber "Shemeber") of
[Zeboiim](/wiki/Zeboyim "Zeboyim"), and the unnamed king of [Bela](/wiki/Zoara
"Zoara") (later called Zoar).

In response, Elam's King [Chedorlaomer](/wiki/Chedorlaomer "Chedorlaomer"),
gathered additional forces from [Shinar](/wiki/Shinar "Shinar"),
[Ellasar](/wiki/Ellasar "Ellasar") and [Goyim](/wiki/Goyim "Goyim") to
suppress this rebellion from the cities of the plain. They waged war in the
[Vale of Siddim](/wiki/Battle_of_Siddim "Battle of Siddim") in the 14th year.
The battle was brutal with heavy losses in the cities of the plain, with their
resultant defeat, [Genesis 14:10](http://www.mechon-
mamre.org/p/pt/pt0114.htm#10). Sodom and Gomorrah were spoiled of their goods,
and captives were taken, including Lot. The tide of war turned when Lot's
uncle, [Abraham](/wiki/Abraham "Abraham"), gathered an elite force that
slaughtered King Chedorlaomer's forces in Hobah, north of
[Damascus](/wiki/Damascus "Damascus"). The success of his mission freed the
cities of the plain from under Elam's rule.

### The Judgment upon Sodom and
Gomorrah[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sodom_and_Gomorrah&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: The Judgment upon Sodom and Gomorrah")]

See also: [Hospitality § Judaism](/wiki/Hospitality#Judaism "Hospitality")

The story of the judgment of Sodom and Gomorrah is told in [Genesis
18-19](http://www.mechon-mamre.org/p/pt/pt0118.htm#1). Three men, thought by
most commentators to have been angels appearing as men,[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] came to
Abraham in the plains of Mamre. After the angels received the hospitality of
Abraham and Sarah, his wife, "the Lord" revealed to Abraham that he would
confirm what he had heard against Sodom and Gomorrah, "and because their sin
is very grievous".

In response, Abraham inquired of the Lord if he would spare the city if 50
righteous people were found in it, to which the Lord agreed he would not
destroy it for the sake of the righteous yet dwelling therein. Abraham then
inquired of God for mercy at lower numbers (first 45, then 40, then 30, then
20, and finally at 10), with the Lord agreeing each time.[36] Two angels were
sent to Sodom to investigate and were met by Abraham's nephew
[Lot](/wiki/Lot_\(biblical_person\) "Lot \(biblical person\)"), who convinced
the angels to lodge with him, and they ate with Lot.

[Genesis 19:4-5](http://www.mechon-mamre.org/p/pt/pt0119.htm#4) described what
followed, which confirmed its end:

> 4 But before they lay down, the men of the city, even the men of Sodom,
> compassed the house round, both young and old, all the people from every
> quarter.  
>  5 And they called unto Lot, and said unto him: 'Where are the men that came
> in to thee this night? bring them out unto us, that we may know them.'
>
> ([NRSV](/wiki/New_Revised_Standard_Version "New Revised Standard Version"):
> know them, [NIV](/wiki/New_International_Version "New International
> Version"): can have sex with them, [NJB](/wiki/New_Jerusalem_Bible "New
> Jerusalem Bible"): can have intercourse with them).

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Nuremberg_chronicles_f_21r.png/220px-
Nuremberg_chronicles_f_21r.png)](/wiki/File:Nuremberg_chronicles_f_21r.png)

[](/wiki/File:Nuremberg_chronicles_f_21r.png "Enlarge")

Sodom and Gomorrah from the [Nuremberg Chronicle](/wiki/Nuremberg_Chronicle
"Nuremberg Chronicle") by [Hartmann Schedel](/wiki/Hartmann_Schedel "Hartmann
Schedel"), 1493. [Lot's wife](/wiki/Lot%27s_wife "Lot's wife"), already
transformed into a salt pillar, is in the center.

Lot refused to give his guests to the inhabitants of Sodom and, instead,
offered them his two [virgin](/wiki/Almah "Almah") daughters "which have not
_known_ man" and to "do ye to them as _[is]_ good in your eyes". However, they
refused this offer, complained about this alien, namely Lot, giving orders,
and then came near to break down the door. Lot's angelic guests rescued him
and struck the men with blindness and they informed Lot of their mission to
destroy the city. Then (not having found even 10 righteous people in the
city), they commanded Lot to gather his family and leave. As they made their
escape, one angel commanded Lot to "look not behind thee" (singular "thee").
However, as Sodom and Gomorrah were destroyed with [brimstone and
fire](/wiki/Fire_and_brimstone "Fire and brimstone") from the Lord, [Lot's
wife](/wiki/Lot%27s_wife "Lot's wife") looked back at the city, and she became
a pillar of salt.

## Other
references[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sodom_and_Gomorrah&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Other references")]

[Major](/wiki/Major_prophets "Major prophets") and [minor
prophets](/wiki/Minor_prophets "Minor prophets") in the [Hebrew
Bible](/wiki/Hebrew_Bible "Hebrew Bible") have referred to Sodom and Gomorrah
to parallel their prophetic events. The [New Testament](/wiki/New_Testament
"New Testament") also contains passages of parallels to the destruction and
surrounding events that pertained to these cities and those who were involved.
Later [deuterocanonical](/wiki/Deuterocanonical "Deuterocanonical") texts
attempt to glean additional insights about these cities of the Jordan Plain
and their residents.

### Moses[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sodom_and_Gomorrah&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Moses")]

Moses referred to the destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah in [Deuteronomy
29:22-23](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Deuteronomy+29%3A22-23&version=9%3BNIV):

> "Your children who follow you in later generations and foreigners who come
> from distant lands will see the calamities that have fallen on the land and
> the diseases with which the Lord has afflicted it. The whole land will be a
> burning waste of salt and sulfur—nothing planted, nothing sprouting, no
> vegetation growing on it. It will be like the destruction of Sodom and
> Gomorrah, [Admah](/wiki/Admah "Admah") and [Zeboyim](/wiki/Zeboyim
> "Zeboyim"), which the Lord overthrew in fierce anger." —NIV

  
See also: [Deuteronomy
32:32-33](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Deuteronomy+32%3A32-33&version=NRSV)

### Major
Prophets[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sodom_and_Gomorrah&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Major Prophets")]

[Isaiah
1:9-10](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Isaiah+1%3A9-10&version=NRSV),
[Isaiah
3:9](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Isaiah+3%3A9&version=NRSV)
and [Isaiah
13:19-22](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Isaiah+13%3A19-22&version=NRSV)
addresses people as from Sodom and Gomorrah, associates Sodom with shameless
sinning and tells Babylon that it will end like those two cities.

[Jeremiah
23:14](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Jeremiah+23%3A14&version=NRSV),
[Jeremiah
49:17-18](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Jeremiah+49%3A17-18&version=NRSV),
[Jeremiah
50:39-40](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Jeremiah+50%3A39-40&version=NRSV)
and [Lamentations
4:6](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Lamentations+4%3A6&version=NRSV)
associate Sodom and Gomorrah with adultery and lies, prophesies the fate of
Edom, south of the Dead Sea, predicts the fate of Babylon and uses Sodom as a
comparison.

In [Ezekiel
16:48-50](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Ezekiel+16%3A48-50&version=NIV),
God compares [Jerusalem](/wiki/Jerusalem "Jerusalem") to Sodom, saying "Sodom
never did what you and your daughters have done." He explains that the sin of
Sodom was that "She and her daughters were arrogant, overfed and unconcerned;
they did not help the poor and needy. They were haughty and did detestable
things before me."

### Minor
Prophets[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sodom_and_Gomorrah&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Minor Prophets")]

In [Amos
4:1-11](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Amos+4%3A1-11&version=NIV),
God tells the Israelites that although he treated them like Sodom and
Gomorrah, they still did not repent.

In [Zephaniah
2:9](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Zephaniah+2%3A9&version=NIV),
[Zephaniah](/wiki/Zephaniah "Zephaniah") tells Moab and Ammon, southeast and
northeast of the Dead Sea, that they will end up like Sodom and Gomorrah.

### New
Testament[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sodom_and_Gomorrah&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: New Testament")]

In [Matthew
10:1-15](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Matthew+10%3A1-15&version=NIV),
cf. [Luke
10:1-12](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Luke+10%3A1-12&version=NIV),
Jesus declares certain cities more damnable than Sodom and Gomorrah, due to
their response to Jesus' disciples, in the light of greater grace
([RSV](/wiki/Revised_Standard_Version "Revised Standard Version")):

> "And if any one will not receive you or listen to your words, shake off the
> dust from your feet as you leave that house or town. Truly, I say to you, it
> shall be more tolerable on the day of judgment for the land of Sodom and
> Gomor'rah than for that town."

In [Matthew
11:20-24](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Matthew+11%3A20-24&version=NIV),
Jesus prophesies the fate of some cities where he did some of his works
([RSV](/wiki/Revised_Standard_Version "Revised Standard Version")):

> "And you, Caper'na-um, will you be exalted to heaven? You shall be brought
> down to Hades. For if the mighty works done in you had been done in Sodom,
> it would have remained until this day. But I tell you that it shall be more
> tolerable on the day of judgment for the land of Sodom than for you."

In [Luke
17:28-30](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Luke+17%3A28-30&version=NRSV),
Jesus compares his second-coming to the judgment of Sodom and Gomorrah
([RSV](/wiki/Revised_Standard_Version "Revised Standard Version")):

> "Likewise as it was in the days of Lot—they ate, they drank, they bought,
> they sold, they planted, they built, but on the day when Lot went out from
> Sodom fire and sulphur rained from heaven and destroyed them all—so will it
> be on the day when the Son of man is revealed."

In [Romans
9:29](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Romans+9%3A29&version=RSV),
[Paul the Apostle](/wiki/Paul_the_Apostle "Paul the Apostle") quotes [Isaiah
1:9](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Isaiah+1%3A9&version=NRSV)
([RSV](/wiki/Revised_Standard_Version "Revised Standard Version")): "And as
Isaiah predicted, 'If the Lord of hosts had not left us children, we would
have fared like Sodom and been made like Gomor'rah.'"

In [2 Peter
2:4-10](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=2+Peter+2%3A4-10&version=NRSV),
[Saint Peter](/wiki/Saint_Peter "Saint Peter") says that just as God destroyed
Sodom and Gomorrah and saved Lot, he will deliver godly people from
temptations and punish the wicked on Judgement Day.

[Jude
1:7](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Jude+1%3A7&version=NRSV)
records that both Sodom and Gomorrah were "giving themselves over to
fornication, and going after strange flesh, are set forth for an example,
suffering the vengeance of eternal fire".

[Revelation
11:7-8](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Revelation+11%3A7-8&version=NRSV)
makes an allegorical use of Sodom when it describes the places where the [two
witnesses](/wiki/Two_witnesses "Two witnesses") will descend during the
[Apocalypse](/wiki/Apocalypse "Apocalypse").

### Deuterocanonical
references[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sodom_and_Gomorrah&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Deuterocanonical references")]

[Wisdom
10:6-8](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Wisdom+10%3A6-8&version=RSV)
refers to the [Five Cities](/wiki/Pentapolis#Significant_historical_cases
"Pentapolis"):

> Wisdom rescued a righteous man when the ungodly were perishing; he escaped
> the fire that descended on the Five Cities. Evidence of their wickedness
> still remains: a continually smoking wasteland, plants bearing fruit that
> does not ripen, and a pillar of salt standing as a monument to an
> unbelieving soul. For because they passed wisdom by, they not only were
> hindered from recognizing the good, but also left for mankind a reminder of
> their folly, so that their failures could never go unnoticed.

[Wisdom
19:17](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Wisdom+19%3A17&version=GNT)
says that the Egyptians who enslaved the Israelites were "struck with
blindness, like the men of Sodom who came to the door of that righteous man
Lot. They found themselves in total darkness, as each one groped around to
find his own door."

[Sirach
16:8](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Sirach+16%3A8&version=RSV)
says "[God] did not spare the neighbors of Lot, whom he loathed on account of
their insolence."

In [3 Maccabees
2:5](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=3+Maccabees+2%3A5&version=RSV),
the high priest Simon says that God "consumed with fire and sulphur the men of
Sodom who acted arrogantly, who were notorious for their vices; and you made
them an example to those who should come afterward".

[2 Esdras
2:8-9](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=2+Esdras+2%3A8-9&version=RSV)
says "Woe to you, Assyria, who conceal the unrighteous in your midst! O wicked
nation, remember what I did to Sodom and Gomor′rah, whose land lies in lumps
of pitch and heaps of ashes. So will I do to those who have not listened to
me, says the Lord Almighty."

[2 Esdras
5:1-13](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=2+Esdras+5%3A1-13&version=RSV)
describes signs of the [end times](/wiki/End_time "End time"), one of which is
that "the sea of Sodom shall cast up fish".

In [2 Esdras
7:106](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=2+Esdras+7%3A106&version=RSV),
[Ezra](/wiki/Ezra "Ezra") says that Abraham prayed for the people of Sodom.

## Religious
views[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sodom_and_Gomorrah&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Religious views")]

### Jewish[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sodom_and_Gomorrah&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Jewish")]

[Rictor Norton](/wiki/Rictor_Norton "Rictor Norton") views classical Jewish
texts as stressing the cruelty and lack of [hospitality](/wiki/Hospitality
"Hospitality") of the inhabitants of Sodom to the "stranger".[37] The people
of Sodom were seen as guilty of many other significant sins.
[Rabbinic](/wiki/Rabbi "Rabbi") writings affirm that the Sodomites also
committed economic crimes, blasphemy and bloodshed.[38] One of the worst was
to give money or even gold ingots to beggars, after inscribing their names on
them, and then subsequently refusing to sell them food. The unfortunate
stranger would end up starving and after his death, the people who gave him
the money would reclaim it.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

[Jon D. Levenson](/wiki/Jon_D._Levenson "Jon D. Levenson") views a rabbinic
tradition described in the [Mishnah](/wiki/Mishnah "Mishnah") as postulating
that the sin of Sodom was a violation of conventional hospitality in addition
to homosexual conduct, describing Sodom's lack of generosity with the saying,
"What is mine is mine; what is yours is yours" (_m. Avot_ 5.10).[39]

A modern orthodox position is one that holds, "The paradigmatic instance of
such aberrant behavior is found in the demand of the men of Sodom to 'know'
the men visiting Lot, the nephew of Abraham, thus lending their name to the
practice of 'sodomy'."[40]

[Jay Michaelson](/wiki/Jay_Michaelson "Jay Michaelson") proposes a reading of
the story of Sodom that emphasizes the violation of hospitality as well as the
violence of the Sodomites. "Homosexual rape is the way in which they violate
hospitality—not the essence of their transgression. Reading the story of Sodom
as being about homosexuality is like reading the story of an ax murderer as
being about an ax."[41] Michaelson places the story of Sodom in context with
other Genesis stories regarding Abraham's hospitality to strangers, and argues
that when other texts in the Hebrew Bible mention Sodom, they do so without
commentary on homosexuality. The verses cited by Michaelson include Jeremiah
23:14,[[Jeremiah
23:14]](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Jeremiah+23%3A14&version=KJ21)
where the sins of Jerusalem are compared to Sodom and are listed as adultery,
lying, and strengthening the hands of evildoers; Amos 4:1-11 (oppressing the
poor and crushing the needy);[[Amos
4:1-11]](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Amos+4%3A1-11&version=KJ21)
and Ezekiel 16:49-50,[[Ezekiel
16:49-50]](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Ezekiel+16%3A49-50&version=KJ21)
which defines the sins of Sodom as "pride, fullness of bread, and abundance of
idleness was in her and in her daughters, neither did she strengthen the hand
of the poor and needy. And they were haughty, and did _toevah_ before me, and
I took them away as I saw fit." Michaelson uses _toevah_ in place of
_abomination_ to emphasize the original Hebrew, which he explains as being
more correctly translated as "taboo".[42]

###
Christian[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sodom_and_Gomorrah&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Christian")]

Several theories have been advanced in [Christian](/wiki/Christian
"Christian") thought concerning the sin of Sodom. One area of dispute is
whether the mob was demanding the homosexual rape of Lot's guests. A second
area of dispute is whether the act of homosexuality or the act of
inhospitality and violence towards foreigners is the more significant ethical
downfall of Sodom.[43][44]

The first contention between the two positions primarily focuses upon the
meaning of the Hebrew verb ידע (yada), translated as _know_ in the King James
Version:

> And they called unto Lot, and said unto him, Where [are] the men which came
> in to thee this night? bring them out unto us, that we may know them.
> —[Genesis
> 19:5](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Genesis+19%3A5&version=9)

However, the word "know" in the King James Version has been used to refer to
sexual intercourse. One example can be found in [Genesis
4:1](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Genesis+4%3A1&version=KJV)
between Adam and Eve:

> And Adam knew Eve his wife; and she conceived, and bare Cain, and said, I
> have gotten a man from the LORD.—[Genesis
> 4:1](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Genesis+4%3A1&version=KJV)

Some Hebrew scholars believe that _yada_ , unlike the English word _know_ ,
requires the existence of a "personal and intimate relationship".[45] For this
reason, many of the most popular of the 20th century translations, including
the New International Version, the New King James Version, and the New Living
Translation, translate _yada_ as "have sex with" or "know ... carnally" in
[Gen
19:5](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Gen+19%3A5&version=NRSV)[46]

Those who favor the non-sexual interpretation argue against a denotation of
sexual behavior in this context, noting that while the Hebrew word for _know_
appears over 900 times in the Hebrew Scriptures, only approximately 1% (13–14
times)[37][47] of those references is it clearly used as a euphemism for
realizing sexual intimacy.[48] Instead, those who hold to this interpretation
usually see the demand to know as demanding the right to interrogate the
strangers.[49]

Countering this is the observation that one of the examples of _know_ meaning
to know sexually occurs when Lot responds to the [Gen
19:5](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Gen+19%3A5&version=NRSV)
request, by offering his daughters for rape, only three verses later in the
same narrative:

> Behold now, I have two daughters which have not known man; let me, I pray
> you, bring them out unto you, and do ye to them as is good in your eyes:
> only unto these men do nothing.... —[Genesis
> 19:8](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Genesis+19%3A8&version=NRSV)

The following is a major text in regard to these conflicting opinions:

> Even as Sodom and Gomorrah, and the cities about them in like manner, giving
> themselves over to fornication, and going after strange flesh, are set forth
> for an example, suffering the vengeance of eternal fire. —[Jude
> 1:7](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Jude+1%3A7&version=NRSV)

This reference to "going after strange flesh" is understood in different ways
to include something akin to bestiality, having illicit sex with strangers,
having sex with angels, but most often God's destruction of the populations of
the four cities is interpreted to mean [homosexual](/wiki/Homosexual
"Homosexual") (same-sex) relations.[50]

Many who interpret the stories in a non-sexual context contend that as the
word for "strange" is akin to "another", "other", "altered" or even "next",
the meaning is unclear, and if the condemnation of Sodom was the result of
sexual activities perceived to be perverse, then it is likely that it was
because women sought to commit fornication with "other than human" angels,[51]
perhaps referring to [Genesis
6](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Genesis+6&version=NRSV) or the
apocryphal [Book of Enoch](/wiki/Book_of_Enoch "Book of Enoch"). Countering
this, it is pointed out that [Genesis
6](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Genesis+6&version=NRSV) refers
to angels seeking women, not men seeking angels, and that both Sodom and
Gomorrah were engaged in the sin Jude describes before the angelic visitation,
and that, regardless, it is doubtful that the Sodomites knew they were angels.
In addition, it is argued the word used in the King James Version of the Bible
for "strange", can mean unlawful or corrupted ([Rm.
7:3](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Rm.+7%3A3&version=NRSV);
[Gal.
1:6](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Gal.+1%3A6&version=NRSV)),
and that the apocryphal [Second Book of Enoch](/wiki/Second_Book_of_Enoch
"Second Book of Enoch") (different from the Book of Enoch which Jude quotes
from) condemns "sodomitic" sex (2 Enoch 10:3; 34:1),[52] thus indicating that
homosexual relations was the prevalent _physical_ sin of Sodom.[53]

Both the non-sexual and the [homosexuality](/wiki/Homosexuality
"Homosexuality") view invoke certain classical writings as well as other
portions of the Bible.[54][55]

> Now this was the sin of Sodom: She and her daughters were arrogant, overfed
> and unconcerned; they did not help the poor and needy. They were haughty and
> did detestable things before me. Therefore I did away with them as you have
> seen. —[Ezekiel
> 16:49-50](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Ezekiel+16%3A49-50&version=NRSV)

Here the nonsexual view focuses on the inhospitality aspect, while the other
notes the description _detestable_ or
_[abomination](/wiki/Abomination_\(Bible\) "Abomination \(Bible\)")_ , the
Hebrew word for which often denotes moral sins, including those of a sexual
nature.[56][57]

In the [Gospel of Matthew](/wiki/Gospel_of_Matthew "Gospel of Matthew") (and
corresponding verse) when [Jesus](/wiki/Jesus "Jesus") warns of a worse
judgment for some cities than Sodom, inhospitality is perceived by some as the
sin, while others see it fundamentally being impenitence:

> If anyone will not welcome you or listen to your words, shake the dust off
> your feet when you leave that home or town. I tell you the truth, it will be
> more bearable for Sodom and Gomorrah on the day of judgment than for that
> town. —[Matthew
> 10:14-15](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Matthew+10%3A14-15&version=NRSV)

The nonsexual view focuses on the cultural importance of hospitality, which
this biblical story shares with other ancient civilizations, such as [Ancient
Greece](/wiki/Ancient_Greece "Ancient Greece") and [Ancient
Rome](/wiki/Ancient_Rome "Ancient Rome"), where
[hospitality](/wiki/Hospitality "Hospitality") was of singular importance and
strangers were under the protection of the gods.[58]

Within the Christian Churches that agree on the possible sexual interpretation
of _know_ (yada) in this context, there is still a difference of opinion on
whether homosexuality is important. On its website, the [Anglican
Communion](/wiki/Anglican_Communion "Anglican Communion") presents the
argument that the story is "not even vaguely about homosexual love or
relationships", but is instead "about dominance and [rape](/wiki/Rape "Rape"),
by definition an act of violence, not of sex or love". This argument that the
violence and the threat of violence towards foreign visitors is the true
ethical downfall of Sodom (and not homosexuality), also observes the
similarity between the Sodom and Gomorrah and the [Battle of
Gibeah](/wiki/Battle_of_Gibeah "Battle of Gibeah") Bible stories. In both
stories, an inhospitable mob demands the homosexual rape of a foreigner or
foreigners. As the mob instead settles for the rape and murder of the
foreigner's female concubine in the Battle of Gibeah story, the homosexual
aspect is generally seen as inconsequential, and the ethical downfall is
understood to be the violence and the threat of violence towards foreigners by
the mob. This [Exodus
22:21-24](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Exodus+22%3A21-24&version=NRSV)
lesson is viewed by Anglicans as a more historically accurate way to interpret
the Sodom and Gomorrah story.[43][59]

###
Islamic[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sodom_and_Gomorrah&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Islamic")]

Main article: [Lot in Islam](/wiki/Lot_in_Islam "Lot in Islam")

The Quran contains twelve references to "the people of Lut", the biblical Lot,
but meaning the residents of Sodom and Gomorrah (references 6:86-90; 7:80–84;
11:74–83; 15:58-77; 21:74-75; 26:160–173; 27:54–58; 29:28–30, 33-35;
37:133-138; 51:32-37; 54:33-38 and 66:10), and their destruction by God is
associated explicitly with their sexual practices:[60][61]

The 'people of Lot' transgressed consciously against the bounds of God. Their
avarice led to inhospitality and robbery, which in turn led to the humiliation
of strangers by mistreatment and rape. It was their [abominable
sin](/wiki/Islamic_views_on_sin "Islamic views on sin") of homosexual sex
which was seen as symptomatic of their attitudes,[62][63] and upon Lot's
exhorting them to abandon their transgression against God, they ridiculed
him,[64] and threatened him with dire consequences;[63][65][66] Lot only
prayed to God to be saved from doing as they did. Then Gabriel met Lot and
said that he must leave the city quickly, as God had given this command to Lot
for saving his life. In the Quran it was written that Lot's wife stayed behind
as she had transgressed. She met her fate in the disaster, and only Lot and
his family were saved during the destruction of their city,[67] with the
understanding that the cities of Sodom and Gomorrah are identified in Genesis,
but "the location remains unnamed in the Qur'an"[68]

In the Quran, surah (chapter) 26 Ash-Shu`arā' (The Poets) –

> So, We saved him and his family, all. Except an old woman among those who
> remained behind.
>
> — [Quran](/wiki/Quran "Quran")
> [26:170–171](http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A2002.02.0006%3Asura%3D26%3Averse%3D170)

> Commentary: This was his wife, who was a bad old woman. She stayed behind
> and was destroyed with whoever else was left. This is similar to what Allah
> says about them in Surat Al-A`raf and Surat Hud, and in Surat Al-Hijr, where
> Allah commanded him to take his family at night, except for his wife, and
> not to turn around when they heard the Sayhah as it came upon his people. So
> they patiently obeyed the command of Allah and persevered, and Allah sent
> upon the people a punishment which struck them all, and rained upon them
> stones of baked clay, piled up.
>
> — [Tafsir ibn Kathir](/wiki/Tafsir_ibn_Kathir "Tafsir ibn Kathir")
> (Commentary by [Ibn Kathir](/wiki/Ibn_Kathir "Ibn Kathir"))[69]

## Modern
Sodom[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sodom_and_Gomorrah&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Modern Sodom")]

The site of the present [Dead Sea Works](/wiki/Dead_Sea_Works "Dead Sea
Works"), a large operation for the extraction of Dead Sea minerals, is called
"_Sdom_ " (סדום) according to its traditional Arab name, _Khirbet as-sudūm_
(خربت السدوم). Nearby is [Mount Sodom](/wiki/Mount_Sodom "Mount Sodom") (הר
סדום in Hebrew and جبل السدوم in Arabic) which consists mainly of salt. In the
Plain of Sdom (מישור סדום) to the south there are a few springs and two small
agricultural villages, Neot Hakikar and Ein Tamar[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_].

## Second World
War[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sodom_and_Gomorrah&action=edit&section=17 "Edit
section: Second World War")]

"Operation Gomorrah" was the appropriate name given to the [Bombing of
Hamburg](/wiki/Bombing_of_Hamburg_in_World_War_II "Bombing of Hamburg in World
War II") in July 1943, in which 42,600 civilians were killed, and where use of
incendiaries caused a vortex and whirling updraft of super-heated air which
created a 460 meter high tornado of fire.
